body:
<!-- Before reporting: search existing issues and check the FAQ. -->

- `nvim --version`: `NVIM v0.5.0-nightly-4-gbedab7e87`
- `vim -u DEFAULTS` (version: ) behaves differently? N/A
- Operating system/version: ubuntu-16.04
- Terminal name/version: kitty -> ssh -> tmux
- `$TERM`: tmux

### Steps to reproduce using `nvim -u NORC`

1. setup treesitter for go and enable TS syntax highlighting for go
2. open up the contents of https://gist.github.com/entombedvirus/19038b42b09439b227b0c6e75d977f5c in a .go file
3. jump to line 29, insert line above using `O`
4. type `x :` as if to type ` x := 1`

### Actual behaviour

As soon that `:` is pressed, the message area should now `Error executing lua callback: ...7e/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua:145: end_col value outside range` while still in `INSERT` mode.

NOTE: The error doesn't repro at different files or even in different lines in the same file. But I have 100% repro on that specific line on that specific file.

I added some extra logging to `treesitter/highlighter.lua`:

```
      if hl then
        local status, err = pcall(function()
            a.nvim_buf_set_extmark(self.buf, ts_hs_ns, start_row, start_col, {
                end_col = end_col,
                end_line = end_row,
                hl_group = hl
            })
        end)
        if not status then
            print(vim.inspect{
                status = status,
                err = err,
                start_row = start_row,
                start_col = start_col,
                end_col = end_col,
                end_line = end_row,
                hl_group = hl
            })
        end
      end

```

and got the following output:

```
{                                                                                                                                                                                         
  end_col = 24,                                                                                                                                                                           
  end_line = 30,                                                                                                                                                                          
  err = "...7e/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua:146: end_col value outside range",                                                                                   
  hl_group = 310,                                                                                                                                                                         
  start_col = 31,                                                                                                                                                                         
  start_row = 27,                                                                                                                                                                         
  status = false                                                                                                                                                                          
}                                                                                                                                                                                         
{                                                                                                                                                                                         
  end_col = 4,                                                                                                                                                                            
  end_line = 30,                                                                                                                                                                          
  err = "...7e/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua:146: end_col value outside range",                                                                                   
  hl_group = 338,                                                                                                                                                                         
  start_col = 0,                                                                                                                                                                          
  start_row = 30,                                                                                                                                                                         
  status = false                                                                                                                                                                          
}                                                                                                                                                                                         
{                                                                                                                                                                                         
  end_col = 6,                                                                                                                                                                            
  end_line = 30,                                                                                                                                                                          
  err = "...7e/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua:146: col value outside range",                                                                                       
  hl_group = 312,                                                                                                                                                                         
  start_col = 5,                                                                                                                                                                          
  start_row = 30,                                                                                                                                                                         
  status = false                                                                                                                                                                          
}                                                                                                                                                                                         
{                                                                                                                                                                                         
  end_col = 7,                                                                                                                                                                            
  end_line = 30,                                                                                                                                                                          
  err = "...7e/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua:146: col value outside range",                                                                                       
  hl_group = 345,                                                                                                                                                                         
  start_col = 6,                                                                                                                                                                          
  start_row = 30,                                                                                                                                                                         
  status = false                                                                                                                                                                          
}   
```

### Expected behaviour

no error messages.

comment_data.body: Hey, thanks for the report ! I _think_ that this is actually related to  #12867, just leaving that there for the record.
I couldn't repro with the gist but I do run into this issue all the time seemingly at random with go + treesitter. Currently at version `NVIM v0.5.0-847-gad5652724`.
Happened with a Python file that contained a syntax error. Currently at `v0.5.0-nightly-244-g6af64d384`

This has been a consistent, many different filetype problem for the last 5 HEADs I've tried over the last month. Rust, shell, yaml, javascript, typescript, it happens to all of them, and moreover (nobody has mentioned this) it destroys the highlighting for that file, spraying random highlights all over the place like a toddler got into the Sharpie box. You can fix it with `:e` but then it comes back pretty quickly. You probably don't want to release 0.5.0 without fixing it.
lets see if tj did anything with the bytes validator, otherwise i will take it back :D

> it destroys the highlighting for that file, spraying random highlights all over the place

This indeed happens, usually when I format my code outside the editor (via CLI) and then focus it back.

> usually when I format my code outside the editor (via CLI) 

This is a bit more specific, and thus testable and actionable :]

I am working on a byte edit debug tool but it is still a bit rough https://github.com/tjdevries/nsync.nvim/pull/1.
My goal is to produce something that looks almost like failing testcases that people can just submit as issues.

Come to think of it `git checkout` might be responsible for a large number of the instances for me. I couldn't say whether it's all of them, but it could be. I have been swapping branches quite a lot.
@BK1603 I think this is related to our `:checktime` thing, but I am not sure yet.
Hmm reloading a buffer _used_ to detach it, thus should force tree-sitter to re-attach and re-parse from scratch. perhaps this chain of logic has been broken somewhere?
I think that the path took by `checktime` and `edit` are not the same, thus causing that.

Can confirm that this is also happening for me in javascript and lua.
Is there a way to restart the treesitter without doing `:e` ?
The `checktime` issue is fixed on latest master (and next nightly built tonight). Please remind me of other issues with a clear step-by-step reproduce :D

@bfredl I managed to reproduce it like this.

Having this lua content:
```lua
vim.cmd[[augroup numbertoggle]]
  vim.cmd [[autocmd!]]
  vim.cmd [[autocmd BufEnter,FocusGained,InsertLeave,WinEnter * if &nu | set rnu   | endif]]
  vim.cmd [[autocmd BufLeave,FocusLost,InsertEnter,WinLeave   * if &nu | set nornu | endif]]
vim.cmd[[augroup END]]
```
And when typing in this command:
```
:%s/]]/
```

I get the error:
![screenshot](https://i.imgur.com/jIRIwlr.png)

I know that's not a valid lua syntax, but i wouldn't expect error to show up like that.
I think the above error relates to #12967, not sure if you have `inccommand` enabled in your config @kristijanhusak.
@akinsho Yeah I have it enabled, so it's probably that.
@kristijanhusak Cool, I will write the test case and hopefully also fix it :]

Hey, I think I shortcutted you.

Could you please try https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13539 and se if it fixes your issue ?

@bfredl I found another way to reproduce this.

1. Edit some file that has treesitter enabled and that is part of some git repo (I tested with lua file). Leave neovim opened on that file.
2. Open new terminal, go to the repo folder, and remove the changes you just did with git (i did `git reset --hard origin/master`)
3. Go back to the first neovim, see same error happening.

Usually when I get these errors, it is when I focus neovim after doing something outside of it.
@kristijanhusak is this latest neovim? because it sounds just like the error I just fixed.

@bfredl yeah, latest master.
```
NVIM v0.5.0-dev+1009-g0efc71313
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
```
![ts-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1782860/103694714-b8917e00-4f9b-11eb-9c94-37ec6fe668de.gif)
This happens to me constantly too. My version is the NVIM v0.5.0-dev+1025-g0fad952a2.
same on `NVIM v0.5.0-dev+1050-g78f0f00cd`

Same on
```
NVIM v0.5.0-dev+nightly-324-g4d1fc167a
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
```

@bfredl Is there a way to reload the highlights for a buffer? Currently i'm fixing this issue by doing `:edit`, but that's not really working when I have unsaved changes in the buffer. I just want to set up autocmd that will reload highlights on FocusGained.
What I do is a combination of both : `:write` then `:edit` which can be automated in a function

" Autoread.(editor)
`    map <leader>a :e<cr>`

It happens to me on python when I create a new line setting a couple of classs variables, if I remove smartindent and autoindent from vimrc then no error shows up.
version: v0.5.0-dev+1016-g0af5a56e4

@luisiacc oh that's interesting, I remember we had issues with smartindent before... Could you provide a minimal reproducing example?

@horta yup I think I remember this one too, but having your reproduction steps will definitely help, thanks!
Treesitter is great, super fast. I would be using it despite that bug =P

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13895 seems to have fixed this for me, when testing with the steps described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12967#issuecomment-774072640

I'll have to use it longer before I'm convinced it takes care of all edge cases, but I'm hopeful!
I will check it with my bug.c file.

I confirmed that my issue from commenet https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12861#issuecomment-754876035 is fixed. 
I ran into similar problem when doing undo after trying to reproduce the steps.

1. Edit some file that has treesitter enabled and that is part of some git repo (I tested with lua file). Leave neovim opened on that file.
2. Open new terminal, go to the repo folder, and remove the changes you just did with git (i did git reset --hard origin/master)
3. Go back to the first neovim, see that file now refreshed and that content you just added is properly removed. No errors at this point, this was now fixed.
4. Try to undo changes that you just removed, error appears

Here's the gif:
![ts-undo-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1782860/107659518-7f79b700-6c87-11eb-81e3-25aff63200d0.gif)

The bug (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12861#issuecomment-774786548) persists with HEAD tree-sitter + neovim (commit 1aec5ba...)

![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/514522/107660860-9ec11600-6c80-11eb-92ff-a7e37713c8ed.gif)
how is `vim.lsp.buf.formatting()` implemented? by a sequence of `nvim_buf_set_text` ?

Issue described by @kristijanhusak can be reliably reproduced with smaller config and without git (using nvim/treesitter from current master):

testrc.vim:
```vim
call plug#begin('~/.local/share/nvim/plugged')
Plug 'nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter'
call plug#end()
lua require('nvim-treesitter.configs').setup{highlight={enable = true}}
```

```sh
$ echo "print('boo')" > test.py && vim -u testrc.vim test.py
```
inside vim (reproduces manually, does not reproduce when sourced as script):
```vim
:norm yyp
:w
:!echo "print('boo')" > %
:undo            " bug is already here (note wrong highlight)
:undo
:redo
:redo
```

![vim](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2602750/107684641-4d764e00-6ca3-11eb-965e-de79549f635e.gif)

> how is `vim.lsp.buf.formatting()` implemented? by a sequence of `nvim_buf_set_text` ?

It uses `vim.lsp.util.apply_text_edits` which under the hood currently uses `nvim_buf_set_lines` but there is [a PR](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13703) to change it to use `nvim_buf_set_text`
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13935 fixed error msg after undo/redo :D Still I noticed some highlighting issue (described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13937)
not sure if noted elsewhere but diffput seems to fail sometimes.

From recent builds neovim started throwing some of these errors in the command line. For example I get this one a lot sometimes:

```
Error executing vim.schedule lua callback: /usr/local/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/highlight.lua:37: Line number outside range
```

Edit:
Also these appears sometimes:
```
Error detected while processing InsertLeave Autocommands for "<buffer=5>":
```

I'm not exactly sure how to reproduce it yet.
+1 @kristijanhusak I get this error as well atleast twice daily. It seems to occur when operating on a large chunk of code at once, although I can't reproduce this at the moment.

I'm pretty sure this happens to me with python and js when switching git branches while having existing neovim sessions open and then they reload the content. Altough I think recently this problem has mildened a bit; before the entire treesitter highlighting got disabled and there were `col value outside range` errors, now the errors still appear but some of the highlighting still works.
@kristijanhusak that's probably not tree-sitter tho. We need to enable better tracebacks for `vim.schedule` so we can see what code invokes `vim.highlight` here
@bfredl is there a way to debug it?

@bfredl I figured it out. It was caused by efm-langserver returning `-1` for line range for diagnostics in files that are ignored (efm + eslint + ignored file with eslint). Switching to diagnosticls fixes the issue. Sorry for bothering.

Edit: Maybe built in treesitter should handle these negative ranges and force them to 0?

Here is how I am able to reproduce it, consistently, on my setup. Apologies if it doesn't reproduce on anyone else's.

`nvim --version`: `NVIM v0.5.0-dev+1157-g0ab88c2ea`
I have the `nvim-treesitter` plugin, with the `cpp` parser installed and up-to-date.
`tree-sitter -V`: `tree-sitter 0.19.3`

[Here's one of the couple files that the bug occurs on for me](https://gist.github.com/sarahkittyy/1ba1abe2ba053a11d8322d25c73d6a01)

It's pulled from a random project of mine, I didn't have it in me to search through and try to hunt for the most minimal working example as it seems to happen on some files and not others.

Steps to reproduce:
- Open the file.
- Go to line 39 (maybe it works on any line, I'm just trying to be specific)
- Enter insert mode, hit `TAB`

Immediately, it breaks:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31551546/111738989-a9129900-8858-11eb-98ae-aa5f94f7f31c.png)

Here's hoping someone else can reproduce this. :D

EDIT: Using `noexpandtab, tabstop=4, softtabstop=4, shiftwidth=4`. But I think that all that matters is the TAB character itself, it doesn't happen with `expandtab`.
@sarahkittyy cannot reproduce. Perhaps options are important. What is your values of expandtab, tabstop, softtabstop and shiftwidth?
@bfredl noexpandtab, tabstop=4, softtabstop=4, shiftwidth=4
@sarahkittyy  see #14124 - I believe this pr should fix your issue, and general issues with treesitter and `noexpandtab`.

This happens to me when editing rust files, but only after inserting a tab character. It was difficult to pin point the error as most of the error message was inline and didn't fit my terminal screen, so I couldn't read what the error code actually was.
@SandWoodJones Are you using `noexpandtab`?
yes
@SandWoodJones  Then can you try #14124 to see if that fixes the issue?
@ZymoticB  Just to confirm, you don't see errors when your language server is disabled, correct? Are you using any auto-formatting from your language server?

@chentau If I disable my language server I cannot reproduce, that is correct.

I'm honestly pretty new to a lot these pieces in neovim so I'm not sure if my language server is automatically formatting / providing indent information. I don't think it is though, I have a keybinding to `lua vim.lsp.buf.formatting()` that I use to explicitly format a file.
Oh, its worth mentioning that I do have indent enabled for tree-sitter, however, I am able to reproduce the errors with tree-sitter indent disabled.

I am still having this error randomly, when undoing multiple times and redoing back to the normal state in a cpp file. I see that there is some movement to fix this issue, but just so I know, should this already be fixed in the nightly build?

@fcomoreira1 It's generally more helpful/relevant to know exactly what edits you were doing before the undo/redo, since in this case, it is most likely not undo or redo itself that causes an invalid update, but rather the undoing/redoing of a specific editing command (maybe `dd`, or `<c-v>5jc`. It would be great if you could provide that.

Here is a minimal example to get this error using tree-sitter-python and highlights module:

1. open a python file with following content: `a=1`
2. perform :luado return "aa"

I think there has to be highlighted color on column that will be outside the new text, therefore the short string `aa`. With a longer string (3 or more character) the error is not produced.

The only content of my unit.vim is to enable treesitter highlighting:

```
packadd nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter

lua <<EOF
require'nvim-treesitter.configs'.setup {
  ensure_installed = {python}, -- one of "all", "maintained", or a list of languages
  highlight  = {enable = true},
}
EOF
```
The `luado` problem should (hopefully) be resolved by #14318

Have the same issue using `deno-fmt` on my TS code with `efm-language-server`. Installed nvim using `brew`, same issue with v0.5.0-dev+cd3e74201, v0.5.0-dev+bb7d3790b efm setup: ``` local deno_fmt = {formatCommand = "deno fmt -", formatStdin = true} local lua_fmt = {formatCommand = "lua-format -i", formatStdin = true} nvim_lsp.efm.setup { on_attach = on_attach_common, init_options = {documentFormatting = true}, filetypes = {"typescript", "typescriptreact" }, settings = { rootMarkers = {".git/"}, languages = { lua = { lua_fmt }, typescript = { deno_fmt }, typescriptreact = { deno_fmt }, } } } ``` then running either `:lua vim.lsp.buf.formatting()` or `:lua vim.lsp.buf.formatting_sync({}, 1000)` manually. LSPInfo looks all fine and green. Tried to check some debugging info using ``` lua vim.lsp.set_log_level("debug") lua vim.cmd('e'..vim.lsp.get_log_path()) ``` But not sure what to look for? Screenshot error: For now I switched to a Neoformat setup that's running `deno fmt`, with which I have no problems (so far) Let me know if there's something specific I could do or check!

I had the same problem. It occured with my custom (lua) version of [parinfer_rust](https://github.com/eraserhd/parinfer-rust) which is kind of a autoformatter. Formatting is done after each modification. At first, my custom plugin used `nvim_buf_set_lines()` to set the whole buffer whenever something changed. When I changed it to set only changed rows, the error discussed in this issue started happening annoyingly often.

I changed the plugin to use `nvim_buf_set_text()` instead of `nvim_buf_set_lines()` and errors dissappeared (the area was exactly the same). I also tried `vim.fn.setline()` and no errors.

Wild guess: Using `nvim_buf_set_lines()` sometimes causes invalid change object to be sent to `treesitter`. That function is propably used in numerous plugins.

Can people experiencing issues with treesitter and LSP please try out #14501 and let me know if that PR helps out at all? It's a bit difficult for me to test LSP issues, since I don't use a language server.

Hi @chentau I just tried to your branch (e0a5eb732, chentau/extmark_setlines) and there I can not reproduce the issue anymore. Maybe still possible but I couldn't, switching back to `origin master` (516551319) I can reproduce it again. 

(Please note I'm clueless about neovim on code level, so can't comment on your PR :))

Even with all the latest fixes I'm still getting this error sometimes, though it happens very rarely now, so we are making progress!

Sadly I haven't run into any easy to reproduce cases yet.

Lsp issues should pretty much be fixed in latest master (sorry for breaking packer), but bug reports will still be very helpful. I think the remaining issues are probably edge cases that will be difficult to track down.

I think it should be possible to do random testing here.  Just perform random edits and this error should not occur?

> breaking packer), but bug reports will still be very helpful. I think the

It display a white text.

It happens at least once an hour now. Cannot reproduce the steps, but I can confirm that 
1. Writing the file
2. Deleting the buffer `:bdelete`
3. Re opening the file
Seems to be my fix till we see it actually get fixed
@d3fkon what works for me is deleting the line that shows the treesitter error, and then undo
@d3fkon @marcelbeumer The easiest way  to repair the broken state is by running `:e`.

I was having this issue while using prettier/vim-prettier plugin all the time while writing ts and tsx files.

Switching to https://github.com/sbdchd/neoformat did the trick.

Just FYI

Interesting, then we should compare those two plugins to see how they differ.
It may be something like a command that causes the problem.

I have been getting this a lot using vimdiff, via tpope's vim-fugitive / `:Gdiffsplit`. Making many kinds of small edits to file in diff view causes the error. It's using the vimdiff folding strategy.

On latest unstable and still seeing this issue with Treesitter + vim prettier in JS files. Can reproduce by opening a .js file. Making a change that needs formatting and hitting `<leader>p` to format which successfully formats the file but causes this error and broken highlighting

I have the same problem in C code (CoC) randomly and quite often. In most cases code reformat or `dd` causes what. Pretty sure the race condition here.

Hi guys! Sometimes this bug makes me bored a bit so I've made the investigation and gonna do some steps to resolve this issue. Let me briefly explain my investigation trip and propose possible solution. As mentioned above this bug is due to improper synchronization of treesitter tree state and nvim buffer state. I have a good example code which reproduces this bug with high probability - a simple svelte code snippet with prettier formatted. Almost 1/2 code formats ended with the error. Heres is the code: ```svelte ``` The `prettier` code which modifies nvim buffer and applys formatted text: ```vim autoload/prettier/utils/buffer.vim: " delete all lines on the current buffer silent! execute 'lockmarks %delete _' " replace all lines from the current buffer with output from prettier let l:idx = 0 for l:line in l:newBuffer silent! lockmarks call append(l:idx, l:line) let l:idx += 1 endfor " delete trailing newline introduced by the above append procedure silent! lockmarks execute '$delete _' ``` Then I located the place where treesitter tree receives updates (along with several other trivial places where tree:parse() called): https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua#L415 ```lua function LanguageTree:_on_bytes(bufnr, changed_tick, start_row, start_col, start_byte, old_row, old_col, old_byte, new_row, new_col, new_byte) self:invalidate() local old_end_col = old_col + ((old_row == 0) and start_col or 0) local new_end_col = new_col + ((new_row == 0) and start_col or 0) -- Edit all trees recursively, together BEFORE emitting a bytes callback. -- In most cases this callback should only be called from the root tree. self:for_each_tree(function(tree) tree:edit(start_byte,start_byte+old_byte,start_byte+new_byte, start_row, start_col, start_row+old_row, old_end_col, start_row+new_row, new_end_col) end) ... ``` `on_bytes` events produced by `nvim_buffer_attach()` in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua#L62 ```lua ... a.nvim_buf_attach(self:source(), false, {on_bytes=bytes_cb, on_detach=detach_cb, on_reload=reload_cb, preview=true}) ``` **Looking ahead the following causes of this bug:** 1. `on_bytes` event fired not in all edit cases (some kind of evens never fired) 1. `on_bytes` event data for some cases is incorrect (I will show below) Especially for hurry guys here is the **dumb and durty workaround** which will work in most (but not all) cases: ```diff --- a/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua +++ b/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua @@ -416,20 +416,7 @@ function LanguageTree:_on_bytes(bufnr, changed_tick, start_row, start_col, start_byte, old_row, old_col, old_byte, new_row, new_col, new_byte) - self:invalidate() - - local old_end_col = old_col + ((old_row == 0) and start_col or 0) - local new_end_col = new_col + ((new_row == 0) and start_col or 0) - - -- Edit all trees recursively, together BEFORE emitting a bytes callback. - -- In most cases this callback should only be called from the root tree. - self:for_each_tree(function(tree) - tree:edit(start_byte,start_byte+old_byte,start_byte+new_byte, - start_row, start_col, - start_row+old_row, old_end_col, - start_row+new_row, new_end_col) - end) - + self:invalidate(true) self:_do_callback('bytes', bufnr, changed_tick, start_row, start_col, start_byte, old_row, old_col, old_byte, ``` Returning to my svelte example, I logged `on_bytes` events during code format and found the following sequence of changes: ``` start_row=6 start_col=36 start_byte=131 old_row=0 old_col=0 old_byte=0 new_row=0 new_col=1 new_byte=1 start_row=6 start_col=36 start_byte=131 old_row=0 old_col=1 old_byte=1 new_row=0 new_col=0 new_byte=0 start_row=20 start_col=0 start_byte=673 old_row=1 old_col=0 old_byte=675 new_row=0 new_col=0 new_byte=0 ``` But wait! There is `20 buffer append` events? ``` for l:line in l:newBuffer silent! lockmarks call append(l:idx, l:line) ``` and why the last line edit (`$delete _`) has `old_byte=675`? it obviously should have value `old_byte=1`. ``` silent! lockmarks execute '$delete _' ``` So here are signs of core problem what require some code refactoring: 1. `on_bytes` buffer notifications is wrongly coupled with `extmarks` code and for example when you do modifications with `lockmarks` option - no events will be fired. Curiosly `lockmarks` has not effect for the last `$delete _` command (I've debugged and this flag gone away for some reason) 2. We have a problem with the last line deletion events (`old_byte=675`) which caused by the following line https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/src/nvim/extmark.c#L542 replacing it with `old_byte = (bcount_t)buf->deleted_bytes;` resolves this issue. Currently I have quite vague understanding of meaning of `delete_bytes2` field. ## My proposition Move `on_bytes,..` staff away from extmarks closer to the buffer state, may be `change.c` will be good place for it. and fix here missing `on_bytes` events and check again events data consistency. I may start preparing required changes in 1-2 weeks but help from project veterans will be invaluable here =)

> Move on_bytes,.. staff away from extmarks closer to the buffer state, may be change.c will be good place for it.
and fix here missing on_bytes events and check again events data consistency.

Extmarks are already as close to buffer state you can get. instead what we need to do is have `lockmarks` not affect extmark code at all.

> I may start preparing required changes in 1-2 weeks but help from project veterans will be invaluable here =)

go ahead, don't be afraid to ping us for any question :+1:
Fix and test case landed waiting for review
